text.p: The lawyer of former Argentina World Cup player Alberto Tarantini said on Tuesday her client was not a drug addict and was innocent of charges of trafficking.

The defender in Argentina's 1978 World Cup winning team was arrested in a weekend drugs swoop on a flat in an upper-class Buenos Aires district. Police, who also detained his 21-year old woman companion, said they found cocaine in his possession.

"He was not carrying drugs," said his lawyer Elena Tarubi. She admitted on local radio that Tarantini was voluntarily submitting himself to drug treatment, but said, "He does not admit that he is a drug addict. He is not dependent on drugs."

Police say they suspect Tarantini, who played for Argentine clubs Boca Juniors and River Plate before playing in England, France and Switzerland, of organising a drugs ring operating in Buenos Aires discotheques.

But Tarantini alleges the police planted drugs on him. The former player was also arrested in March for possession of the drug "ecstasy" but was freed 10 days later on the grounds that it was for his personal use.
"I am innocent and I don't consume or sell drugs," Tarantini said on Monday as he was taken by police into a judge's office, "They did the same thing to me that they did to me last time."
Tarubi said that Tarantini had no need to get involved in drugs smuggling, and that he made enough money for his needs working in the import-export business.
